Award.AwardTitle: ABI Development: BISQUE - Scalable Image Informatics for Quantitative Biology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of California Santa Barbara is awarded a grant to develop a collaborative environment for biological image sciences based on the emerging paradigm of cloud-computing and web-based protocols. Recent advances in microscopy imaging, image processing and computing technologies enable large-scale biological experiments that generate not only large collections of images and video, but also pose new computing and information processing challenges. This project addresses core challenges concerning large scale, unstructured biological images and video collections. These include providing ubiquitous access to images, videos and metadata resources; creating easily accessible image and video analysis, visualizations and work flows; and publishing both data and analysis resources. Streamlining collaborative efforts across teams with online virtual environments will improve scientific productivity, enhance understanding of complex phenomena and allow a growing number of researchers to quantify conditions based on image evidence that so far have remained subjective. The BISQUE (Bio-Image Semantic Query and Environment) open-source platform is being developed keeping these requirements in mind. This project will focus on scalability issues concerning analysis and annotations, computational scalability with distributed computing and cloud enabled services, sophisticated new methods for video and 3D-5D image analysis/visualization, and validation and curation of data and methods. Furthermore, the project will provide individual researchers and laboratories with the means to publish and share data and analysis techniques, thus creating opportunities for cross-fertilization of ideas.

The research will lead to new paradigms for management of image data in diverse scientific fields. One specific area that will immediately benefit is quantitative biology, where large-scale quantitative analysis of information will enable new scientific discoveries and reproducible results. The Bisque platform, with its web-enabled tools and seamless support for demanding computations, will allow diverse labs to publish both scientific datasets and analysis in an easy to use form. Bisque will be used in teaching and research by graduate and undergraduate students. There will be opportunities for undergraduates and high-school students for summer research internships. Through workshops, online tutorials, video demos, and the iPlant discovery environment, this project will ensure outreach to a broader spectrum of researchers. For more information and access to the Bisque platform, visit the website at http://www.bioimage.ucsb.edu/bisque.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This ABI Development project's primary objective is to develop and extend the functionalities of BisQue, a novel, cloud-based imageinformatics software.  Bisque allows users to store, annotate, share and process biological images. The system is built to manage and analyze both data artifacts and metadata for large scale datasets.

During the course of this project we extended the functionalities of the core infrastructure by building support for large scale annotations of big imaging data and facilitating data analysis through a modular analysis system. This included building support for new data formats that are common in bio-medical imaging applications, such as the DICOM format for MRI/CT images that further helped new partnerships with researchers in neuroscience. We released a unique browser-based and plugin-less Direct Volume renderer for 3D and 4D datasets which supports various imaging modalities including fluorescence, MRI and CT. This viewer is utilizing the power of image services in decoding various image formats and serving volumetric data to the client as well as modern browser?s support for WebGL API. At the time of its first release in 2017, this component was the first and only open-source direct volume rendering viewer. Other research groups have incorporated this technology within their own systems.

BisQue uses a simple web browser in the front-end, posing challenges to complex multimodal data visualization. We further extended the annotation and summarization capabilities, including visualization options for 3D data. One of major outcomes is the contanerization of all of BisQUe services using the evolving docker technology. This enables a high performance single-server Bisque installation in less 15 minutes including production database and front-end web-services.  Finaly, we added support for high-throughput workflows and their visualization.

BisQue software is released as open source and offered as a core service through the NSF supported CyVerse cyberinfrastructure. The project has tained a number of undergraduate and graduate students in various aspects of systems software engineering, image processing and computer vision for bioimaging, and machine learning, Finally, a new private start-up, supported initially by the NSF iCore, has licensed the software for commercialization.
